Award.AwardTitle: Revealing Hidden Safety Hazards Using Workers' Collective Bodily and Behavioral Response Patterns

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Current hazard-identification efforts in safety management are mostly limited by humans' abilities to recognize hazards and/or by their existing knowledge of known hazards. Consequently, numerous hazards go unidentified, creating unmanageable risks. To enhance hazard recognition capabilities, this research focuses on understanding and exploiting humans' bodily and behavioral responses in their interaction with the physical environmental system. It is well recognized that a potential hazard within the system may cause instability in actions, and ultimately accidents. However, the unpredictable nature of human behavior poses a critical challenge in utilizing the analysis of such actions for the identification of unstable system conditions. Methodologies developed in this research will enable the evaluation of collective patterns associated with human responses to estimate the likelihood of hazard locations across a construction site. Thus, knowledge gained from this research will advance our ability to utilize response information for accident prevention, leading to reduced injuries and fatalities from construction-related accidents. Research outcomes will be integrated into engineering curriculum development, undergraduate research activities, industry workshops, and outreach activities for K-12 students and underrepresented student groups, especially women and minorities.

The objective of this research is to examine whether, how, and to what extent workers' collective bodily and behavioral response patterns identify recognized/unrecognized hazards for the purpose of enhancing safety performance in construction environments. This research focuses on detecting hazards that causes fall accidents, a single most dangerous injury event within the construction industry, using workers - kinematic sensing data captured from wearable inertial measurement sensors. This research hypothesizes that the collective abnormalities apparent in multiple workers' balance and gait in one location is correlated with the likelihood of the presence (and/or the risk) of a recognized/unrecognized fall hazard in that location. To test this hypothesis, this project will: 1) identify appropriate metrics that characterize the perturbation to workers' balance and gait caused by recognized and unrecognized hazards; 2) model a near-miss index (NMI) that evaluates the abnormalities of workers' gait and balance; 3) investigate the relationship between the collective NMI patterns and the presence and risk of a hazard in each location; 4) identify and examine appropriate sensor network platforms for the scalable implementation of the approach; and 5) validate the efficacy and usefulness of the developed approach through its application within construction sites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To enhance hazard-identification capabilities in dynamic and unpredictable construction environments, this NSF project developed a technique to capture collective anomaly in workers’ bodily and behavioral response patterns and examined the association between collective anomaly and environmental hazards on construction jobsites. In particular this project focused on hazards that causes slip/trip/fall (STF) accidents, a single most dangerous injury event in the construction industry.

To this end, the project team studied changes in a worker’s gait pattern alongside the changes’ spatial locations, considering the fact that STFs often begin with bad interactions between a foot and floor-surface conditions. As its first step, the team investigated and confirmed that gait metrics computed from a single ankle-worn inertial measurement unit (IMU) sensor were sensitive enough to capture disruption caused by common STF hazards on a construction jobsite. Then the project team developed the technique to evaluate the abnormalities of gait-related metrics and created a system to collects and visualize workers’ gait abnormality in a semi real-time. The experiments conducted in laboratory and field settings demonstrated the association between STF hazards and collective abnormalities identified from the system. In addition, a multiple transmit power assisted sequence-based localization (MPSBL) solution was developed to provide a robust localization solution for workers and hazardous areas in semi-outdoor construction environment. PSBL is found to provide a higher accuracy than existing sequence-based localization (SBL) techniques. PSBL is expected to be integrated with the hazard identification system and enhance the location precision of the system. Consequently, these outcomes contribute to identifying STF hazards in a proactive manner and help construction managers eliminate the risk of hazards without depending exclusively upon observations or hazard reporting from a construction worker. 

In addition, this NSF project extends the project outcomes to constructing smart and connected community, by creating a human-centric sensing framework that identifies and locates neighborhoods’ built environments’ physical disorders (PDs) in semi real-time. The experimental results indicated the spatial association between collective anomalies found in pedestrians’ biosignals (i.e., gait patterns, electrodermal activity) and presence of PDs. The team have developed a saliency detection method that better captures local prominent patterns within physiological signals of pedestrians and its validity have demonstrated using the data collected from the experiments conducted in Lincoln, NE, and Bryan, TX. The team further examined the interplay between biosignals and vision-based features on neighborhood built environment in identifying PDs. In addition to pedestrians’ biosignals, built environment features from neighborhood images were extracted and used in constructing a computational model to detect pedestrians’ distress caused from environmental stressors. It was found that leveraging such multimodal data could enhance predicting accuracy.

The findings from this project were integrated into education and outreach activities and were broadly disseminated to the construction industry and academia through publications, and presentations. The new graduate course on data analytics for construction safety and health was created based on the project outcomes and delivered for three semesters at Texas A&M University. In addition, this project provided training for a number of graduate and undergraduate students, particularly from underrepresented groups, by involving them in research activities.
